awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Gaze-Contingent Eye-Tracking System
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support from Major Research Instrumentation, the eye-tracking system (SR Research EyeLink 1000 Plus) will be acquired.  The project is built upon the interdisciplinary team of one visual cognition researcher and six decision science researchers at Drake University (Des Moines, Iowa).  By integrating the well-established techniques in the visual cognition field, the system enables decision science researchers in the team (economics, marketing, accounting, actuarial science, information management) to examine cognitive mechanisms involved in decision-making processes with a finer resolution than eye-tracking methods typically employed in the fields of decision science research.  The system allows researchers to investigate information-processing mechanisms that operate prior to conscious response. The project is designed not only to make real-world application of visual cognition research more accessible to students, but also to introduce students in the decision science field to a scientific approach of dealing with novel data acquired through systematic empirical investigations.  Because decision science is uniquely concerned with how individuals make optimal choices based on available information, some decision scientists work exclusively with pre-existing data.  The research team also recognizes that popular methods of recruiting students to the research lab through a single department has its limitation to reach out to underrepresented student populations.  To promote diversity, equity and inclusion, multiple mechanisms to recruit and support a wide range of students are built in.

The questions pursued in the present project range across (1) how much attentional control one can exert during memory maintenance (visual cognition), (2) how different ways of presenting the nutrition information shapes one's decision-making process of food choice (marketing), (3) how the lack of opportunities affects one's cognitive mechanisms differently from resource scarcity (economics: psychology of poverty), (4) how a popular survey method (i.e., the choice experiment) can be optimized with powerful perceptual and cognitive manipulations (environmental economics), (5) how visual features of the voluntarily disclosed financial information can minimize the chance that the investors can be misled (accounting), (6) when individuals tend to stop processing the massive amount of disclosure information, and how visualization of the difficult-to-understand section would ease one's comprehension of the product (actuarial science), and (7) how search efficiency of the crucial information can be enhanced in the e-commerce context (information management).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Consistent with the "Abstract at Time of Award" above, the major goal of the project is that the PI will train the decision and data science faculty collaborators in the research team to become proficient with cognitive approaches--including the gaze-contingent eye-tracking programming (the paradigm that allows a computer display to change as a function of where an observer is looking).  

Despite a significant delay caused by [1] the delayed arrival of the final award notice and [2] the rise and increased severity of COVID-19 in the state of Iowa, the following four major activities were accomplished: (a) the installation of the awarded instrument (SR Research EyeLink 1000 Plus), (b) providing the decision/data science faculty collaborators with the general instrument training, through the sessions provided by the vendor's engineer, (c) initiating a specific training for a faculty collaborator by the PI, as each collaborator implements and goes through his/her studies, and (d) establishing an efficient online method for large data sharing within the research team in collaboration with the university ITS.  

The delayed arrival of the final award notice (October 2019) led to (a) the installation of the instrument and (b) the general training by the vendor's engineer in December 2019, which was later than the originally planned dates.  Due to the serially-dependent nature of the four activities listed above, the daily access to the awarded instrument was cut short by the rise of COVID-19 (March 2020), and the subsequent university lockdown caused the further delay in (c) the pace of a specific training for a collaborator provided by the PI (i.e., one-on-one work for designing experiments, programming, data collection and analyses) and (d) establishing an efficient online method for large data sharing in collaboration with the university ITS (started in December 2019, completed in June 2020).  

Although (i) the hands-on training of individual collaborators by the PI continues with social distancing and face covering and (ii) the lines of research included in the awarded proposal continue to be prioritized, the team had to re-configure the original plan by changing the order of the planned activities presented in the awarded proposal, in order to cope with the increased severity of COVID-19.  Specifically, the team brought a particular set of studies that necessitate the online experiment component first.  The awarded gaze-contingent eye-tracking system allows the team to investigate possible information-processing mechanisms that operate prior to one's conscious response (e.g., manual responses used in the online experiment).  For certain studies, in order to design a gaze-contingent eye-tracking experiment with a strong manipulation, it is necessary for the team to obtain manual-response data with the online data collection first.  The data acquired through the online method have kept the PI and research team on the track for the one-on-one individual training.  This re-prioritization turned out be proper as the university lockdown returned earlier than expected in the fall of 2020.  This means that, although the team managed to obtain the IRB approval for in-person data collection with the ramp-up protocol, it remains impossible for the team to collect in-person data with the awarded instrument.  

The research team recognizes that popular methods of recruiting students to the research lab through a single department (e.g., psychology, neuroscience) has its limitation to reach out to under-represented student populations.  The inter-disciplinary research team for this award (the PI from the field of visual cognition and eye-tracking, decision/data science faculty collaborators recruited across five different departments) made it possible to reach out to a wider range of students.  Yet, the issues such as the access to a specific building and the practice of social distancing under the increased severity of COVID-19 have presented certain challenges for students to visit the primary performance site.  First, when participants for a specific experiment are students who belong to the decision/data science programs, the access to the original primary performance site (the PI's lab) via the student ID/key card can be challenging.  Second, the total area of the compartment that the instrument is installed (within the PI's lab) is rather small for the practice of social distancing with the installed instrument (the dimensions of the compartment are in the original proposal).  

Taking these concerns into consideration, the PI and research team set up another performance site in addition to the primary performance site (the PI's lab) within the home building that the listed decision/data science faculty collaborators belong to (Aliber Hall).  Under this setting, even though the project is PI's, when it is necessary and appropriate for social distancing, the in-person eye-tracking experiments are to be conducted in the lab space in Aliber Hall, whose total area is physically larger than the PI's eye-tracking compartment.  

While monitoring the COVID-19 status, the PI and research team strive to recruit and support a wide range of students in the proposed research activities.
